docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush, who campaigned on a promise to bring Republicans and Democrats together on legislation defining patients' rights, raised objections today to the major bipartisan bill addressing the issue in Congress. In addition, White House officials persuaded the chief Republican sponsor of the bill, Representative Charlie Norwood of Georgia, to withhold his name from the legislation, which was unveiled today by senators and House members of both parties. Dr. Norwood said he strongly supported the bill but held back today as a courtesy to the president.

headline.main: Bush Stalling Bipartisan Bill On Rights Of Patients

docs.abstract: President Bush, who campaigned on promise to bring Republicans and Democrats together on legislation defining patients' rights, raises objections to major bipartisan bill before Congress, and persuades Republican Repr Charlie Norwood to withhold his name from legislation; Norwood reiterates strong support, but holds back as courtesy to president; Sen John McCain and Repr Greg Ganske step into Republican breach, joining Sen Edward Kennedy, Repr John Dingell and other Democratic supporters (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain, the maverick Republican who irritated many leaders of his own party in his quest for the presidency, will join Democrats this week in proposing legislation intended to break a three-year impasse over patients' rights. Mr. McCain has come up with what he calls a compromise, hammered out in weeks of negotiations with Democratic senators, including liberals like Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and moderates like John Edwards of North Carolina and Bob Graham of Florida.

headline.main: McCain Joining Democrats To Offer Health Rights Bill

docs.abstract: Republican Sen John McCain will join Democrats in proposing legislation aimed at breaking three-year impasse over patients' rights; reports reaching compromise, hammered out in weeks of negotiations with Democratic senators, including liberals like Edward M Kennedy and moderates like John Edwards and Bob Graham; new bill defines wide variety of patients' rights, including access to emergency care and medical specialists; patients would also receive new rights to sue insurance companies and health maintenance organizations that improperly deny claims or cause injuries (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Computer Sciences Corporation, the No. 3 computer-services company in the nation, said today that its profit fell because of acquisition costs in its most recent quarter. Net income fell to $65.6 million, or 38 cents a share, in the period ended Dec. 29, which was the third quarter of its fiscal year. Profit was down from $82.3 million, or 48 cents, in the quarter a year ago, a company spokesman, Frank Pollare, said.
docs.abstract: Computer Sciences Crop says net income fell to $65.6 million in fiscal third quarter from $82.3 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 13 percent, to $2.66 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Still upset that Al Gore lost despite labor's big campaign push, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said yesterday that unions hoped to work with President Bush on issues like a patients' bill of rights. But the labor leader, John J. Sweeney, said unions would hold Mr. Bush and Republican lawmakers accountable if they took stands that in labor's eyes did not help working families.

headline.main: Labor Looks for Common Ground With Bush

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney, still upset that Al Gore lost despite labor's big campaign push, says in National Press Club address unions hope to work with Pres George W Bush on variety of issues, but will hold him and Republican lawmakers accountable if they take stands that fail to help working families; cites many of Bush's past actions that he views as antilabor; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: During MonaLou Callery's marriage, there were nights when her husband would knock her to the floor and then kick her and choke her until she passed out, or slam her face into the wall, his hand at the back of her head, she later recalled in divorce proceedings against him. In 1983, after six and a half years of abuse, she left him. She found a job, fought for custody of her children and started rebuilding her life. Yet every time she combed her hair or brushed her teeth, the mirror showed a constant reminder of the brutality. Her nose, broken more than 14 times, had settled into a crooked distortion, humped where the bone had scarred.

headline.main: Surgery Heals Scars Both Physical and Emotional

docs.abstract: Dr Mark Rounds and hundreds of other plastic surgeons donate their time and skill to victims of domestic abuse, and their patients get psychological boost from having their facial injuries repaired; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK LAKE GROVE: POLICE ENCOUNTERS DESCRIBED -- Four women spoke publicly for the first time yesterday about what they described as abusive encounters with Suffolk County police officers. The Suffolk County Police Department's Internal Affairs Bureau and the F.B.I. interviewed the women yesterday. One woman, who gave her name only as Ellie, identified an officer who she said had kissed and fondled her during a traffic stop 15 years ago, then harassed her again in 1998 while she was working at a highway construction site. The police would not comment on that case other than to say that the officer still works at the Fifth Precinct in Patchogue, had been investigated by the Internal Affairs Bureau and was at one point suspended from duty. The officer she named is not the same officer accused of making women disrobe after recent traffic stops. Tina Kelley (NYT) HAUPPAUGE: HANDICAPPED-PARKING FINES -- A Suffolk County legislator, Andrew Crecca, announced yesterday that he was introducing a bill to raise the fine for parking illegally in spaces reserved for handicapped drivers by at least $100. Under the measure, the county's share of the fine would rise to $150 from $50 for first-time offenders and to $200 from $50 for repeat violators, said Mr. Crecca, a Republican. The state also imposes a penalty, ranging from $50 to $150. Al Baker (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: If the dawn of the new media world was supposed to mark the beginning of a fun and egalitarian workplace, Silicon Alley appears to have missed the target, according to a report released last week. The report, researched even before the national shakeout in the online industry, shows a transient work force in Manhattan with members worried about keeping their current jobs and ever-trailing in the training needed to find the next ones.

headline.main: Workers in Silicon Alley Feel Underpaid and Fear Losing Jobs, Survey Finds

docs.abstract: Economic Policy Institute study suggests workers in high-tech industries feel they are underpaid, as well as unstable in terms of job security; findings also show pay disparity between genders (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TOO many comedians are making fun of George W. Bush's brainpower without any basis for their jibes. Why not give him a little quiz instead? O.K., Mr. President, which of the following would help the economy most? * A big tax cut skewed toward the rich. * Opening sensitive federal lands to logging and drilling.

headline.main: How New Campaign Laws Would Help the Economy

docs.abstract: Daniel Akst column urges Pres Bush to embrace campaign finance reform, saying it would do more to help American economy than a big tax cut skewed toward the rich or the opening of sensitive federal lands to logging and drilling; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MARY WOODS was fed up. After waiting all day to get a checkup for one of her four children at the county hospital in Valhalla, she had missed the last bus home to Peekskill. She eventually found a ride home. But when she met her friends for lunch the next day, she was determined to avoid repeating the experience.

headline.main: Taking Health Care Into Their Own Hands

docs.abstract: Article traces history of Hudson River HealthCare, which was started in 1971 by group of women in Peekskill, NY, and has become one-stop center offering wide variety of services to more than 17,000 patients a year; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: KATHLEEN McNALLY knows a thing or two about bad credit. She is vice president for financial literacy at the National Foundation for Credit Counseling, an association of 1,500 agencies that help people with financial problems. But even she was taken aback when a second notice from her family doctor was a letter threatening to turn over her bill to a collection agency. She would have paid the first bill, she said, but decided to wait because there was confusion over whether her insurance company had yet paid its portion. After she learned that she was responsible for the amount, she said, ''I paid that bill that very night.''

headline.main: Will Doctors Make Your Credit Sick?

docs.abstract: Doctors, hospitals, laboratories and other providers of health care are increasingly turning to collection agencies to collect sums they claim are owed them by both patients and insurance companies; claims can hurt patients' credit ratings; drawing (M)
